description: Borrowed from Latin rotundus (“round”), from Latin rota (“wheel”), from Proto-Indo-European *Hreth₂- (“to run, to roll”) . Doublet of round, which arrived through Old French/Anglo-Norman.

entries.meaning: Having a round, spherical or curved shape; circular; orbicular.
examples: Convex preferences may have indifference curves that exhibit “flat spots,” while strictly convex preferences have indifference curves that are strictly rotund.

entries.meaning: Having a round body shape; portly or plump; podgy.
(of a sound) Full and rich; orotund; sonorous; full-toned.
